sn35.228:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, an unlearned ordinary person speaks of the ocean.

sn35.228:1.2.eng: But that’s not the ocean in the training of the Noble One.

sn35.228:1.3.eng: That’s just a large body of water, a large sea of water.

sn35.228:1.4.eng: For a person, the eye is an ocean,

sn35.228:1.5.eng: and its currents are made of sights.
sn35.228:1.5.comm: Compare Pañcaviṁśa Brāhmaṇa 6.4.7: “‘Hail to the ocean! Hail to the ocean’s eye!’ he says. For speech is truly the ocean, and mind is the ocean’s eye.”

sn35.228:2.1.pli: Yo taṃ rūpamayaṃ vegaṃ sahati, ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, atari cakkhusamuddaṃ saūmiṃ sāvaṭṭaṃ sagāhaṃ sarakkhasaṃ;
sn35.228:2.1.eng: Someone who can prevail over those currents is said to have crossed over the ocean of the eye, with its waves and whirlpools, its saltwater crocodiles and monsters.
sn35.228:2.1.comm: Explained at Iti 109, AN 4.122, and MN 67.

sn35.228:2.2.eng: Crossed over, gone to the far shore, the brahmin stands on solid ground.

sn35.228:2.3.eng: For a person, the ear … nose … tongue … body …

sn35.228:2.5.pli: Yo taṃ rasamayaṃ vegaṃ sahati, ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, atari jivhāsamuddaṃ saūmiṃ sāvaṭṭaṃ sagāhaṃ sarakkhasaṃ;

sn35.228:2.8.eng: and its currents are made of ideas.

sn35.228:2.9.pli: Yo taṃ dhammamayaṃ vegaṃ sahati, ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, atari manosamuddaṃ saūmiṃ sāvaṭṭaṃ sagāhaṃ sarakkhasaṃ;
sn35.228:2.9.eng: Someone who can prevail over those currents is said to have crossed over the ocean of the mind, with its waves and whirlpools, its saltwater crocodiles and monsters.

sn35.228:2.10.eng: Crossed over, gone to the far shore, the brahmin stands on solid ground.”

sn35.228:2.11.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

sn35.228:2.12.eng: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

sn35.228:3.1.eng: “A knowledge master who’s crossed <j>the ocean so hard to cross,

sn35.228:3.2.eng: with its saltwater crocodiles and monsters, <j>its waves, whirlpools, and dangers;

sn35.228:3.3.eng: they’ve completed the spiritual journey, <j>and gone to the end of the world,

sn35.228:3.4.eng: they’re called ‘one who has gone beyond’.”

sn35.229:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, an unlearned ordinary person speaks of the ocean.

sn35.229:1.2.eng: But that’s not the ocean in the training of the Noble One.

sn35.229:1.3.eng: That’s just a large body of water, a large sea of water.

sn35.229:1.4.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.229:1.4.eng: There are sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn35.229:1.5.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ariyassa vinaye samuddo.
sn35.229:1.5.eng: This is called the ocean in the training of the Noble One.

sn35.229:1.6.pli: Etthāyaṃ sadevako loko samārako sabrahmako sassamaṇabrāhmaṇī pajā sadevamanussā yebhuyyena samunnā tantākulakajātā kulagaṇṭhikajātā muñjapabbajabhūtā, apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ saṃsāraṃ nātivattati …pe….
sn35.229:1.6.eng: And it’s here that this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—is for the most part sunk. It’s become tangled like string, knotted like a ball of thread, and matted like rushes and reeds, and it doesn’t escape the places of loss, the bad places, the underworld, transmigration.

sn35.229:2.1.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, jivhāviññeyyā rasā …pe… santi, bhikkhave, manoviññeyyā dhammā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.229:2.1.eng: There are sounds … smells … tastes … touches … ideas known by the mind, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn35.229:2.2.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ariyassa vinaye samuddo.
sn35.229:2.2.eng: This is called the ocean in the training of the Noble One.

sn35.229:2.3.pli: Etthāyaṃ sadevako loko samārako sabrahmako sassamaṇabrāhmaṇī pajā sadevamanussā yebhuyyena samunnā tantākulakajātā kulagaṇṭhikajātā muñjapabbajabhūtā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ saṃsāraṃ nātivattatīti.
sn35.229:2.3.eng: And it’s here that this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—is for the most part sunk. It’s become tangled like string, knotted like a ball of thread, and matted like rushes and reeds, and it doesn’t escape the places of loss, the bad places, the underworld, transmigration.

sn35.229:3.1.eng: Those in whom greed, hate, and ignorance
sn35.229:3.1.comm: The verses are also in Iti 69.

sn35.229:3.3.eng: have crossed the ocean so hard to cross,

sn35.229:3.4.eng: with its saltwater crocodiles and monsters, <j>its waves and dangers.

sn35.229:4.1.eng: They’ve slipped their chains, given up death, and have no attachments.

sn35.229:4.2.eng: They’ve given up suffering, <j>so there are no more future lives.

sn35.229:4.3.eng: They’ve disappeared, and cannot be measured;

sn35.229:4.4.eng: and they’ve confounded the King of Death, I say.”

sn35.23:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you the all.
sn35.23:1.2.comm: While most teaching templates are shared between the six senses and the aggregates, only the six senses are declared to be the “all”. This is because the six senses cover the entirety of experience, whereas the aggregates select the aspects most prominently grasped as self. For context, see SN 35.28 and notes.

sn35.23:1.5.pli: Cakkhuñceva rūpā ca, sotañca saddā ca, ghānañca gandhā ca, jivhā ca rasā ca, kāyo ca phoṭṭhabbā ca, mano ca dhammā ca—
sn35.23:1.5.eng: It’s just the eye and sights, the ear and sounds, the nose and smells, the tongue and tastes, the body and touches, and the mind and ideas.

sn35.23:1.7.eng: Mendicants, suppose someone was to say:
sn35.23:1.7.comm: The “someone” would be a philosopher of the Upaniṣads, for whom the metaphysical notion of “all” is crucial. The same phrasing is used of the rejection of the “duality” of the senses; see SN 35.92 and notes.

sn35.23:1.8.pli: ‘ahametaṃ sabbaṃ paccakkhāya aññaṃ sabbaṃ paññāpessāmī’ti, tassa vācāvatthukamevassa;
sn35.23:1.8.eng: ‘I’ll deny this all and describe another all.’ They’d have no grounds for that claim,

sn35.23:1.9.pli: puṭṭho ca na sampāyeyya, uttariñca vighātaṃ āpajjeyya.
sn35.23:1.9.eng: they’d be stumped by questions, and, in addition, they’d get frustrated.

sn35.23:1.11.eng: Because they’re out of their element.”
sn35.23:1.11.comm: The brahmins of the Upaniṣads show off their rhetorical prowess through elevated debates. These debates, however, are exceedingly specialized, making sense only for those steeped in Vedic culture and ritual.

sn35.230:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, bāḷisiko āmisagatabaḷisaṃ gambhīre udakarahade pakkhipeyya.
sn35.230:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, suppose an angler was to cast a baited hook into a deep lake.

sn35.230:1.2.eng: Seeing the bait, a fish would swallow it.

sn35.230:1.3.pli: Evañhi so, bhikkhave, maccho gilitabaḷiso bāḷisikassa anayaṃ āpanno byasanaṃ āpanno yathākāmakaraṇīyo bāḷisikassa.
sn35.230:1.3.eng: And so the fish that swallowed the hook would meet with tragedy and disaster, and the angler can do what he wants with it.

sn35.230:2.1.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, chayime baḷisā lokasmiṃ anayāya sattānaṃ vadhāya pāṇinaṃ.
sn35.230:2.1.eng: In the same way, there are these six hooks in the world that mean tragedy and slaughter for living creatures.

sn35.230:2.3.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.230:2.3.eng: There are sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn35.230:2.4.pli: Tañce bhikkhu abhinandati abhivadati ajjhosāya tiṭṭhati.
sn35.230:2.4.eng: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keeps clinging to them,

sn35.230:2.5.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu gilitabaḷiso, mārassa anayaṃ āpanno byasanaṃ āpanno yathākāmakaraṇīyo pāpimato …pe…
sn35.230:2.5.eng: they’re called a mendicant who has swallowed Māra’s hook. They’ve met with tragedy and disaster, and the Wicked One can do with them what he wants.

sn35.230:2.6.eng: There are sounds … smells … tastes … touches …

sn35.230:3.1.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, manoviññeyyā dhammā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.230:3.1.eng: ideas known by the mind, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn35.230:3.2.pli: Tañce bhikkhu abhinandati abhivadati ajjhosāya tiṭṭhati.
sn35.230:3.2.eng: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keeps clinging to them,

sn35.230:3.3.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu gilitabaḷiso mārassa anayaṃ āpanno byasanaṃ āpanno yathākāmakaraṇīyo pāpimato.
sn35.230:3.3.eng: they’re called a mendicant who has swallowed Māra’s hook. They’ve met with tragedy and disaster, and the Wicked One can do with them what he wants.

sn35.230:4.1.pli: Santi ca, bhikkhave, cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.230:4.1.eng: There are sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn35.230:4.2.pli: Tañce, bhikkhu, nābhinandati nābhivadati nājjhosāya tiṭṭhati. Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na gilitabaḷiso mārassa abhedi baḷisaṃ paribhedi baḷisaṃ na anayaṃ āpanno na byasanaṃ āpanno na yathākāmakaraṇīyo pāpimato …pe….
sn35.230:4.2.eng: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them, they’re called a mendicant who hasn’t swallowed Māra’s hook. They’ve broken the hook, destroyed it. They haven’t met with tragedy and disaster, and the Wicked One cannot do with them what he wants.

sn35.230:5.1.eng: There are sounds … smells … tastes … touches …

sn35.230:5.2.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, manoviññeyyā dhammā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.230:5.2.eng: ideas known by the mind, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn35.230:5.3.pli: Tañce bhikkhu nābhinandati nābhivadati nājjhosāya tiṭṭhati, ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na gilitabaḷiso mārassa abhedi baḷisaṃ paribhedi baḷisaṃ na anayaṃ āpanno na byasanaṃ āpanno na yathākāmakaraṇīyo pāpimato”ti.
sn35.230:5.3.eng: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them, they’re called a mendicant who hasn’t swallowed Māra’s hook. They’ve broken the hook, destroyed it. They haven’t met with tragedy and disaster, and the Wicked One cannot do with them what he wants.”

sn35.231:0.3.eng: The Simile of the Latex-Producing Tree

sn35.231:1.1.pli: “Yassa kassaci, bhikkhave, bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyā vā cakkhuviññeyyesu rūpesu yo rāgo so atthi, yo doso so atthi, yo moho so atthi, yo rāgo so appahīno, yo doso so appahīno, yo moho so appahīno tassa parittā cepi cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā cakkhussa āpāthaṃ āgacchanti pariyādiyantevassa cittaṃ; ko pana vādo adhimattānaṃ.
sn35.231:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, take any monk or nun who, when it comes to sights known by the eye, still has greed, hate, and delusion, and has not given them up. If even trivial sights come into their range of vision they overcome their mind, let alone those that are compelling.
sn35.231:1.1.comm: About a dozen discourses refer to a “monk or nun”. It is probable that when discourses were taught, there would have normally been nuns present, just as there were random lay people listening in (SN 35.241:7.1).

sn35.231:1.3.pli: Yo, bhikkhave, rāgo, so atthi, yo doso so atthi, yo moho so atthi, yo rāgo so appahīno, yo doso so appahīno, yo moho so appahīno …pe….
sn35.231:1.3.eng: Because they still have greed, hate, and delusion, and have not given them up.

sn35.231:2.1.pli: Yassa kassaci, bhikkhave, bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyā vā jivhāviññeyyesu rasesu yo rāgo so atthi …pe….
sn35.231:2.1.eng: When it comes to sounds … smells … tastes … touches …

sn35.231:3.1.pli: Yassa kassaci, bhikkhave, bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyā vā manoviññeyyesu dhammesu yo rāgo so atthi, yo doso so atthi, yo moho so atthi, yo rāgo so appahīno, yo doso so appahīno, yo moho so appahīno, tassa parittā cepi manoviññeyyā dhammā manassa āpāthaṃ āgacchanti pariyādiyantevassa cittaṃ; ko pana vādo adhimattānaṃ.
sn35.231:3.1.eng: ideas known by the mind, they still have greed, hate, and delusion, and have not given them up. If even trivial thoughts come into the range of the mind they overcome their mind, let alone those that are compelling.

sn35.231:3.3.pli: Yo, bhikkhave, rāgo, so atthi, yo doso so atthi, yo moho so atthi, yo rāgo so appahīno, yo doso so appahīno, yo moho so appahīno.
sn35.231:3.3.eng: Because they still have greed, hate, and delusion, and have not given them up.

sn35.231:4.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, khīrarukkho assattho vā nigrodho vā pilakkho vā udumbaro vā daharo taruṇo komārako.
sn35.231:4.1.eng: Suppose there was a latex-producing tree—such as a peepal, a banyan, a wavy leaf fig, or a cluster fig—that’s a tender young sapling.
sn35.231:4.1.comm: It is tempting to translate khīra (“milk”) here as “sap”, but the milky liquid exuded by these trees is a distinct substance called latex.

sn35.231:4.2.pli: Tamenaṃ puriso tiṇhāya kuṭhāriyā yato yato ābhindeyya āgaccheyya khīran”ti?
sn35.231:4.2.eng: If a man were to chop it here and there with a sharp axe, would latex come out?”

sn35.231:5.1.pli: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, yassa kassaci bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyā vā cakkhuviññeyyesu rūpesu yo rāgo so atthi, yo doso so atthi, yo moho so atthi, yo rāgo so appahīno, yo doso so appahīno, yo moho so appahīno, tassa parittā cepi cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā cakkhussa āpāthaṃ āgacchanti pariyādiyantevassa cittaṃ; ko pana vādo adhimattānaṃ.
sn35.231:5.1.eng: “In the same way, take any monk or nun who, when it comes to sights known by the eye, still has greed, hate, and delusion, and has not given them up. If even trivial sights come into their range of vision they overcome their mind, let alone those that are compelling.

sn35.231:5.3.pli: Yo, bhikkhave, rāgo so atthi, yo doso so atthi, yo moho so atthi, yo rāgo so appahīno, yo doso so appahīno, yo moho so appahīno …pe….
sn35.231:5.3.eng: Because they still have greed, hate, and delusion, and have not given them up.

sn35.231:6.1.pli: Yassa kassaci, bhikkhave, bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyā vā jivhāviññeyyesu rasesu yo rāgo so atthi …pe….
sn35.231:6.1.eng: When it comes to sounds … smells … tastes … touches …

sn35.231:7.1.pli: Yassa kassaci, bhikkhave, bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyā vā manoviññeyyesu dhammesu yo rāgo so atthi, yo doso so atthi, yo moho so atthi, yo rāgo so appahīno, yo doso so appahīno, yo moho so appahīno, tassa parittā cepi manoviññeyyā dhammā manassa āpāthaṃ āgacchanti pariyādiyantevassa cittaṃ; ko pana vādo adhimattānaṃ.
sn35.231:7.1.eng: ideas known by the mind, they still have greed, hate, and delusion, and have not given them up. If even trivial thoughts come into the range of the mind they overcome their mind, let alone those that are compelling.

sn35.231:7.3.pli: Yo, bhikkhave, rāgo so atthi, yo doso so atthi, yo moho so atthi, yo rāgo so appahīno, yo doso so appahīno, yo moho so appahīno.
sn35.231:7.3.eng: Because they still have greed, hate, and delusion, and have not given them up.

sn35.231:8.1.pli: Yassa kassaci, bhikkhave, bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyā vā cakkhuviññeyyesu rūpesu yo rāgo so natthi, yo doso so natthi, yo moho so natthi, yo rāgo so pahīno, yo doso so pahīno, yo moho so pahīno, tassa adhimattā cepi cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā cakkhussa āpāthaṃ āgacchanti nevassa cittaṃ pariyādiyanti; ko pana vādo parittānaṃ.
sn35.231:8.1.eng: Take any monk or nun who, when it comes to sights known by the eye, has no greed, hate, and delusion left, and has given them up. If even compelling sights come into their range of vision they don’t overcome their mind, let alone those that are trivial.

sn35.231:8.3.pli: Yo, bhikkhave, rāgo so natthi, yo doso so natthi, yo moho so natthi, yo rāgo so pahīno, yo doso so pahīno, yo moho so pahīno …pe….
sn35.231:8.3.eng: Because they have no greed, hate, and delusion left, and have given them up.

sn35.231:9.1.pli: Yassa kassaci, bhikkhave, bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyā vā jivhāviññeyyesu rasesu …pe… manoviññeyyesu dhammesu yo rāgo so natthi, yo doso so natthi, yo moho so natthi, yo rāgo so pahīno, yo doso so pahīno, yo moho so pahīno, tassa adhimattā cepi manoviññeyyā dhammā manassa āpāthaṃ āgacchanti nevassa cittaṃ pariyādiyanti; ko pana vādo parittānaṃ.
sn35.231:9.1.eng: When it comes to sounds … smells … tastes … touches … ideas known by the mind, they have no greed, hate, and delusion left, and have given them up. If even compelling ideas come into the range of the mind they don’t overcome their mind, let alone those that are trivial.

sn35.231:9.3.pli: Yo, bhikkhave, rāgo so natthi, yo doso so natthi, yo moho so natthi, yo rāgo so pahīno, yo doso so pahīno, yo moho so pahīno.
sn35.231:9.3.eng: Because they have no greed, hate, and delusion left, and have given them up.

sn35.231:9.4.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, khīrarukkho assattho vā nigrodho vā pilakkho vā udumbaro vā sukkho kolāpo terovassiko.
sn35.231:9.4.eng: Suppose there was a latex-producing tree—such as a peepal, a banyan, a wavy leaf fig, or a cluster fig—that’s dried up, withered, and decrepit.

sn35.231:9.5.pli: Tamenaṃ puriso tiṇhāya kuṭhāriyā yato yato ābhindeyya āgaccheyya khīran”ti?
sn35.231:9.5.eng: If a man were to chop it here and there with a sharp axe, would latex come out?”

sn35.231:9.8.eng: Because it has no latex left.”

sn35.231:10.1.pli: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, yassa kassaci bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyā vā cakkhuviññeyyesu rūpesu yo rāgo so natthi, yo doso so natthi, yo moho so natthi, yo rāgo so pahīno, yo doso so pahīno, yo moho so pahīno, tassa adhimattā cepi cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā cakkhussa āpāthaṃ āgacchanti nevassa cittaṃ pariyādiyanti; ko pana vādo parittānaṃ.
sn35.231:10.1.eng: “In the same way, take any monk or nun who, when it comes to sights known by the eye, has no greed, hate, and delusion left, and has given them up. If even compelling sights come into their range of vision they don’t overcome their mind, let alone those that are trivial.

sn35.231:10.3.pli: Yo, bhikkhave, rāgo so natthi, yo doso so natthi, yo moho so natthi, yo rāgo so pahīno, yo doso so pahīno, yo moho so pahīno …pe….
sn35.231:10.3.eng: Because they have no greed, hate, and delusion left, and have given them up.

sn35.231:11.1.pli: Yassa kassaci, bhikkhave, bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyā vā jivhāviññeyyesu rasesu …pe….
sn35.231:11.1.eng: When it comes to sounds … smells … tastes … touches …

sn35.231:12.1.pli: Yassa kassaci, bhikkhave, bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyā vā manoviññeyyesu dhammesu yo rāgo so natthi, yo doso so natthi, yo moho so natthi, yo rāgo so pahīno, yo doso so pahīno, yo moho so pahīno, tassa adhimattā cepi manoviññeyyā dhammā manassa āpāthaṃ āgacchanti, nevassa cittaṃ pariyādiyanti; ko pana vādo parittānaṃ.
sn35.231:12.1.eng: ideas known by the mind, they have no greed, hate, and delusion left, and have given them up. If even compelling thoughts come into the range of the mind they don’t overcome their mind, let alone those that are trivial.

sn35.231:12.3.pli: Yo, bhikkhave, rāgo so natthi, yo doso so natthi, yo moho so natthi, yo rāgo so pahīno, yo doso so pahīno, yo moho so pahīno”ti.
sn35.231:12.3.eng: Because they have no greed, hate, and delusion left, and have given them up.”

sn35.232:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā ca sāriputto āyasmā ca mahākoṭṭhiko bārāṇasiyaṃ viharanti isipatane migadāye.
sn35.232:1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Sāriputta and Venerable Mahākoṭṭhita were staying near Varanasi, in the deer park at Isipatana.

sn35.232:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahākoṭṭhiko sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yenāyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā sāriputtena saddhiṃ sammodi.
sn35.232:1.2.eng: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Mahākoṭṭhita came out of retreat, went to Venerable Sāriputta, and exchanged greetings with him.

sn35.232:1.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā mahākoṭṭhiko āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ etadavoca:
sn35.232:1.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to Sāriputta:

sn35.232:2.1.pli: “Kiṃ nu kho, āvuso sāriputta, cakkhu rūpānaṃ saṃyojanaṃ, rūpā cakkhussa saṃyojanaṃ …pe…
sn35.232:2.1.eng: “Reverend Sāriputta, which is it? Is the eye the fetter of sights, or are sights the fetter of the eye?

sn35.232:2.2.pli: jivhā rasānaṃ saṃyojanaṃ, rasā jivhāya saṃyojanaṃ …pe…
sn35.232:2.2.eng: Is the ear … nose … tongue … body …

sn35.232:2.3.pli: mano dhammānaṃ saṃyojanaṃ, dhammā manassa saṃyojanan”ti?
sn35.232:2.3.eng: mind the fetter of ideas, or are ideas the fetter of the mind?”

sn35.232:3.1.pli: “Na kho, āvuso koṭṭhika, cakkhu rūpānaṃ saṃyojanaṃ, na rūpā cakkhussa saṃyojanaṃ.
sn35.232:3.1.eng: “Reverend Koṭṭhita, the eye is not the fetter of sights, nor are sights the fetter of the eye.

sn35.232:3.2.pli: Yañca tattha tadubhayaṃ paṭicca uppajjati chandarāgo taṃ tattha saṃyojanaṃ …pe…
sn35.232:3.2.eng: The fetter there is the desire and greed that arises from the pair of them.

sn35.232:3.3.pli: na jivhā rasānaṃ saṃyojanaṃ, na rasā jivhāya saṃyojanaṃ.

sn35.232:3.4.pli: Yañca tattha tadubhayaṃ paṭicca uppajjati chandarāgo taṃ tattha saṃyojanaṃ …pe…

sn35.232:3.5.pli: na mano dhammānaṃ saṃyojanaṃ, na dhammā manassa saṃyojanaṃ.
sn35.232:3.5.eng: mind is not the fetter of ideas, nor are ideas the fetter of the mind.

sn35.232:3.6.pli: Yañca tattha tadubhayaṃ paṭicca uppajjati chandarāgo taṃ tattha saṃyojanaṃ.
sn35.232:3.6.eng: The fetter there is the desire and greed that arises from the pair of them.

sn35.232:4.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, kāḷo ca balībaddo odāto ca balībaddo ekena dāmena vā yottena vā saṃyuttā assu.
sn35.232:4.1.eng: Suppose there was a black ox and a white ox yoked by a single harness or yoke.

sn35.232:4.2.eng: Would it be right to say that

sn35.232:4.3.pli: ‘kāḷo balībaddo odātassa balībaddassa saṃyojanaṃ, odāto balībaddo kāḷassa balībaddassa saṃyojanan’ti, sammā nu kho so vadamāno vadeyyā”ti?
sn35.232:4.3.eng: the black ox is the yoke of the white ox, or the white ox is the yoke of the black ox?”

sn35.232:4.4.comm: The speaker is unclear in this passage, and should be treated according to the otherwise identical passage at SN 41.1:4.7.

sn35.232:4.5.pli: “Na kho, āvuso, kāḷo balībaddo odātassa balībaddassa saṃyojanaṃ, na odāto balībaddo kāḷassa balībaddassa saṃyojanaṃ.
sn35.232:4.5.eng: The black ox is not the yoke of the white ox, nor is the white ox the yoke of the black ox.

sn35.232:4.6.pli: Yena ca kho te ekena dāmena vā yottena vā saṃyuttā taṃ tattha saṃyojanaṃ.
sn35.232:4.6.eng: The yoke there is the single harness or yoke that they’re yoked by.”

sn35.232:5.1.pli: Evameva kho, āvuso, na cakkhu rūpānaṃ saṃyojanaṃ, na rūpā cakkhussa saṃyojanaṃ.
sn35.232:5.1.eng: “In the same way, the eye is not the fetter of sights, nor are sights the fetter of the eye.

sn35.232:5.2.pli: Yañca tattha tadubhayaṃ paṭicca uppajjati chandarāgo taṃ tattha saṃyojanaṃ …pe…
sn35.232:5.2.eng: The fetter there is the desire and greed that arises from the pair of them.

sn35.232:5.4.pli: na mano dhammānaṃ saṃyojanaṃ, na dhammā manassa saṃyojanaṃ.
sn35.232:5.4.eng: mind is not the fetter of ideas, nor are ideas the fetter of the mind.

sn35.232:5.5.pli: Yañca tattha tadubhayaṃ paṭicca uppajjati chandarāgo, taṃ tattha saṃyojanaṃ.
sn35.232:5.5.eng: The fetter there is the desire and greed that arises from the pair of them.

sn35.232:6.1.pli: Cakkhu vā, āvuso, rūpānaṃ saṃyojanaṃ abhavissa, rūpā vā cakkhussa saṃyojanaṃ, nayidaṃ brahmacariyavāso paññāyetha sammā dukkhakkhayāya.
sn35.232:6.1.eng: If the eye were the fetter of sights, or if sights were the fetter of the eye, this living of the spiritual life for the complete ending of suffering would not be found.

sn35.232:6.2.pli: Yasmā ca kho, āvuso, na cakkhu rūpānaṃ saṃyojanaṃ, na rūpā cakkhussa saṃyojanaṃ;
sn35.232:6.2.eng: However, since this is not the case, but

sn35.232:6.3.pli: yañca tattha tadubhayaṃ paṭicca uppajjati chandarāgo, taṃ tattha saṃyojanaṃ, tasmā brahmacariyavāso paññāyati sammā dukkhakkhayāya …pe….
sn35.232:6.3.eng: the fetter there is the desire and greed that arises from the pair of them, this living of the spiritual life for the complete ending of suffering is found.

sn35.232:7.1.pli: Jivhā, āvuso, rasānaṃ saṃyojanaṃ abhavissa, rasā vā jivhāya saṃyojanaṃ, nayidaṃ brahmacariyavāso paññāyetha sammā dukkhakkhayāya.
sn35.232:7.1.eng: If the ear … nose … tongue … body …

sn35.232:7.2.pli: Yasmā ca kho, āvuso, na jivhā rasānaṃ saṃyojanaṃ, na rasā jivhāya saṃyojanaṃ; yañca tattha tadubhayaṃ paṭicca uppajjati chandarāgo, taṃ tattha saṃyojanaṃ, tasmā brahmacariyavāso paññāyati sammā dukkhakkhayāya …pe….

sn35.232:8.1.pli: Mano vā, āvuso, dhammānaṃ saṃyojanaṃ abhavissa, dhammā vā manassa saṃyojanaṃ, nayidaṃ brahmacariyavāso paññāyetha sammā dukkhakkhayāya.
sn35.232:8.1.eng: mind were the fetter of ideas, or if ideas were the fetter of the mind, this living of the spiritual life for the complete ending of suffering would not be found.

sn35.232:8.2.pli: Yasmā ca kho, āvuso, na mano dhammānaṃ saṃyojanaṃ, na dhammā manassa saṃyojanaṃ;
sn35.232:8.2.eng: However, since this is not the case, but

sn35.232:8.3.pli: yañca tattha tadubhayaṃ paṭicca uppajjati chandarāgo, taṃ tattha saṃyojanaṃ, tasmā brahmacariyavāso paññāyati sammā dukkhakkhayāya.
sn35.232:8.3.eng: the fetter there is the desire and greed that arises from the pair of them, this living of the spiritual life for the complete ending of suffering is found.

sn35.232:9.1.pli: Imināpetaṃ, āvuso, pariyāyena veditabbaṃ yathā na cakkhu rūpānaṃ saṃyojanaṃ, na rūpā cakkhussa saṃyojanaṃ.
sn35.232:9.1.eng: This too is a way to understand how this is so.

sn35.232:9.2.pli: Yañca tattha tadubhayaṃ paṭicca uppajjati chandarāgo, taṃ tattha saṃyojanaṃ …pe…

sn35.232:9.4.pli: na mano dhammānaṃ saṃyojanaṃ, na dhammā manassa saṃyojanaṃ.

sn35.232:9.5.pli: Yañca tattha tadubhayaṃ paṭicca uppajjati chandarāgo, taṃ tattha saṃyojanaṃ.

sn35.232:10.2.eng: with which he sees a sight.

sn35.232:10.3.eng: But he has no desire and greed,

sn35.232:10.4.eng: for his mind is well freed.

sn35.232:10.19.eng: But he has no desire and greed,

sn35.232:10.20.eng: for his mind is well freed.

sn35.232:10.23.eng: But he has no desire and greed,

sn35.232:10.24.eng: for his mind is well freed.

sn35.232:11.1.pli: Iminā kho etaṃ, āvuso, pariyāyena veditabbaṃ yathā na cakkhu rūpānaṃ saṃyojanaṃ, na rūpā cakkhussa saṃyojanaṃ;
sn35.232:11.1.eng: This too is a way to understand how the eye is not the fetter of sights, nor are sights the fetter of the eye.

sn35.232:11.2.pli: yañca tattha tadubhayaṃ paṭicca uppajjati chandarāgo, taṃ tattha saṃyojanaṃ.
sn35.232:11.2.eng: The fetter there is the desire and greed that arises from the pair of them.

sn35.232:11.5.pli: na jivhā rasānaṃ saṃyojanaṃ, na rasā jivhāya saṃyojanaṃ;

sn35.232:11.6.pli: yañca tattha tadubhayaṃ paṭicca uppajjati chandarāgo taṃ tattha saṃyojanaṃ.

sn35.232:11.8.pli: na mano dhammānaṃ saṃyojanaṃ, na dhammā manassa saṃyojanaṃ;
sn35.232:11.8.eng: mind is not the fetter of ideas, nor are ideas the fetter of the mind.

sn35.232:11.9.pli: yañca tattha tadubhayaṃ paṭicca uppajjati chandarāgo, taṃ tattha saṃyojanan”ti.
sn35.232:11.9.eng: The fetter there is the desire and greed that arises from the pair of them.”

sn35.233:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā ca ānando āyasmā ca kāmabhū kosambiyaṃ viharanti ghositārāme.
sn35.233:1.1.eng: At one time the venerables Ānanda and Kāmabhū were staying near Kosambī, in Ghosita’s Monastery.

sn35.233:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā kāmabhū sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā ānandena saddhiṃ sammodi.
sn35.233:1.2.eng: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Kāmabhū came out of retreat, went to Venerable Ānanda, and exchanged greetings with him.
sn35.233:1.2.comm: Kāmabhū discusses Dhamma with the wise layman Citta at SN 41.5 and SN 41.6.

sn35.233:1.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā kāmabhū āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavoca:
sn35.233:1.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to Ānanda:

sn35.233:2.1.pli: “Kiṃ nu kho, āvuso ānanda, cakkhu rūpānaṃ saṃyojanaṃ, rūpā cakkhussa saṃyojanaṃ …pe…
sn35.233:2.1.eng: “Reverend Ānanda, which is it? Is the eye the fetter of sights, or are sights the fetter of the eye?

sn35.233:2.2.pli: jivhā rasānaṃ saṃyojanaṃ, rasā jivhāya saṃyojanaṃ …pe…
sn35.233:2.2.eng: Is the ear … nose … tongue … body …

sn35.233:2.3.pli: mano dhammānaṃ saṃyojanaṃ, dhammā manassa saṃyojanan”ti?
sn35.233:2.3.eng: mind the fetter of ideas, or are ideas the fetter of the mind?”

sn35.233:3.1.pli: “Na kho, āvuso kāmabhū, cakkhu rūpānaṃ saṃyojanaṃ, na rūpā cakkhussa saṃyojanaṃ.
sn35.233:3.1.eng: “Reverend Kāmabhū, the eye is not the fetter of sights, nor are sights the fetter of the eye.

sn35.233:3.2.pli: Yañca tattha tadubhayaṃ paṭicca uppajjati chandarāgo, taṃ tattha saṃyojanaṃ …pe…
sn35.233:3.2.eng: The fetter there is the desire and greed that arises from the pair of them.

sn35.233:3.3.pli: na jivhā rasānaṃ saṃyojanaṃ, na rasā jivhāya saṃyojanaṃ …pe…

sn35.233:3.4.pli: na mano dhammānaṃ saṃyojanaṃ, na dhammā manassa saṃyojanaṃ.
sn35.233:3.4.eng: mind is not the fetter of ideas, nor are ideas the fetter of the mind.

sn35.233:3.5.pli: Yañca tattha tadubhayaṃ paṭicca uppajjati chandarāgo taṃ tattha saṃyojanaṃ.
sn35.233:3.5.eng: The fetter there is the desire and greed that arises from the pair of them.

sn35.233:4.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, kāḷo ca balībaddo odāto ca balībaddo ekena dāmena vā yottena vā saṃyuttā assu.
sn35.233:4.1.eng: Suppose there was a black ox and a white ox yoked by a single harness or yoke.

sn35.233:4.2.eng: Would it be right to say that

sn35.233:4.3.pli: ‘kāḷo balībaddo odātassa balībaddassa saṃyojanaṃ, odāto balībaddo kāḷassa balībaddassa saṃyojanan’ti, sammā nu kho so vadamāno vadeyyā”ti?
sn35.233:4.3.eng: the black ox is the yoke of the white ox, or the white ox is the yoke of the black ox?”

sn35.233:4.5.pli: “Na kho, āvuso, kāḷo balībaddo odātassa balībaddassa saṃyojanaṃ, napi odāto balībaddo kāḷassa balībaddassa saṃyojanaṃ.
sn35.233:4.5.eng: The black ox is not the yoke of the white ox, nor is the white ox the yoke of the black ox.

sn35.233:4.6.pli: Yena ca kho te ekena dāmena vā yottena vā saṃyuttā, taṃ tattha saṃyojanaṃ.
sn35.233:4.6.eng: The yoke there is the single harness or yoke that they’re yoked by.”

sn35.233:4.7.pli: Evameva kho, āvuso, na cakkhu rūpānaṃ saṃyojanaṃ, na rūpā cakkhussa saṃyojanaṃ …pe…
sn35.233:4.7.eng: “In the same way, the eye is not the fetter of sights, nor are sights the fetter of the eye.

sn35.233:4.9.eng: mind is not the fetter of ideas, nor are ideas the fetter of the mind.

sn35.233:4.10.pli: yañca tattha tadubhayaṃ paṭicca uppajjati chandarāgo, taṃ tattha saṃyojanan”ti.
sn35.233:4.10.eng: The fetter there is the desire and greed that arises from the pair of them.”
